Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Plug and Play Photosynthesis for RuBisCO Independent Fuels
Award.AbstractNarration:
While solar bioenergy is potentially an abundant and environmentally benign energy source, natural photosynthesis is relatively inefficient owing to slow steps in the conversion of carbon dioxide into biomass. This project seeks to increase energy capture by photosynthesis by diverting energy away from the normal slow steps to potentially more efficient processes. The first major goal of the project is to demonstrate that energy, in the form of electrical current produced by photosynthetic organisms, can be transmitted from a photosynthetic, energy capturing cell to an energy-storing "factory cell" via biological nanowires (biowires). The second major goal of the proposed work is to show that the factory cell can be engineered to use energy to produce useful fuel compounds.

Broader Impacts: This project will create the foundation for new directions in bioenergy research, with potential for dramatic increases in the efficiency of solar energy capture and storage, while training the next generation of scientists and engineers needed to compete in emerging areas of bioenergy and biotechnology. The project will demonstrate that energy can be transferred directly between cells as bio-electricity. Furthermore, the biowire to be developed will serve as a future generic connector for electrically connecting distinct cell types to create novel, functional biofilms. The photosynthetic components constructed in this project will serve as prototypes to establish a new design paradigm. In addition to these benefits, the project will 1) provide valuable resources to catalyze other important research projects, 2) train undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral fellows in areas of technology relevant to critical national needs, 3) establish productive international collaborations, and 4) disseminate information relevant to basic and applied research and development in energy and biotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photosynthesis is the biological process to convert sunlight and carbon dioxide into chemical energy and make reduced molecules, also known as, fuels. Photosynthesis serves as a model and platform for human production of renewable, solar fuels, but it has not been evolved for use in human applications. The goal of this project is to capture excess light energy ordinarily not used in photosynthesis and use it for production of fuels. The strategy to achieve that goal is to create new electrical pathways for photosynthetically-derived electrical current, reducing equivalents, to be shunted to new fuel production modules. To achieve this goal, we have characterized the electrical pathways of photosynthesis in a model cyanobacterium: Synechocystis sp. PCC 6803. We developed an electrochemical method to measured photosynthetically-derived current at the outside of the microorganism. This is a measure of electrons available for alternative fuel production pathways. We also demonstrated the ability to both increase and decrease the amount of this current by introducing or removing electrical sinks. In essence, we demonstrated that we can rewire the electrical pathways between the light-harvesting apparatus of Synechocystis and the outside of the cell. These results have been reported in the peer-reviewed scientific literature and at numerous scientific conferences.

Global climate change precipitates an urgent need to develop new methods to produce renewable fuels. This project contributes to the basic science knowledge that underpins new solar fuel production strategies. In addition to its scientific impacts, this project has had significant impact in the training of researchers at undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral levels. They have been training to conduct research in a use-inspired, interdisciplinary and international project. The post-doctoral research fellow also gained experience mentoring more junior researchers, preparing him for a career in science management and education. The scientific results have been disseminated in a number of traditional scientific and popular science venues including peer-reviewed publication, disciplinary conferences, the 2012 annual meeting of the American Academy for Advancement of Science, Fast Company Magazine, and the popular science blog Microbe World sponsored by the American Society for Microbiology.
